headline: This week’s covers

children.data: , including this one, we publish more than one cover. In most of the world, we consider how technology is turning the business of culture upside down in the year of Disney’s centenary.
Disney’s troubles show how technology has changed the business of culture
As Disney turns 100, its business is on a rollercoaster ride
In mainland Europe we voice concerns that Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, could turn a flawed democracy into a full-blown autocracy.
Turkey could be on the brink of dictatorship
Turkey faces an election that could decide its future as a democracy

bodyText:
Some weeks, including this one, we publish more than one cover. In most of the world, we consider how technology is turning the business of culture upside down in the year of Disney’s centenary.

Leader: Disney’s troubles show how technology has changed the business of culture
Briefing: As Disney turns 100, its business is on a rollercoaster ride
In mainland Europe we voice concerns that Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, could turn a flawed democracy into a full-blown autocracy.

Leader: Turkey could be on the brink of dictatorship
Special report: Turkey faces an election that could decide its future as a democracy
For subscribers only: to see how we design each week’s cover, sign up to our weekly Cover Story newsletter.

parts.description: How we saw the world

parts.headline: Disney’s troubles show how technology has changed the business of culture
parts.description: At 100, the mouse can still roar. But it faces a new kind of rival

parts.headline: Turkey could be on the brink of dictatorship
parts.description: President Erdogan could tip his country over the edge

parts.headline: Excess deaths are soaring as health-care systems wobble
parts.description: What lessons can be learned from a miserable winter across the rich world?

parts.headline: South Africa’s collapsing railway company is a cautionary tale
parts.description: A “developmental state” is less useful than keeping the lights on and trains running

parts.headline: How to sell to the young
parts.subheadline: Don’t try to dig what we all say
parts.description: A myth-busting memo for your boss

parts.headline: Letters to the editor
parts.subheadline: On free speech, Starlink terminals, America’s towns, future populations, weight, Pope Benedict’s shoes, food, presents
parts.description: A selection of correspondence

_metadata.title: The Economist - This week’s covers | The world this week | The Economist
_metadata.headline: This week’s covers
author: The Economist
_metadata.articleBody:
Some weeks, including this one, we publish more than one cover. In most of the world, we consider how technology is turning the business of culture upside down in the year of Disney’s centenary.

Leader: Disney’s troubles show how technology has changed the business of culture
Briefing: As Disney turns 100, its business is on a rollercoaster ride
In mainland Europe we voice concerns that Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, could turn a flawed democracy into a full-blown autocracy.

Leader: Turkey could be on the brink of dictatorship
Special report: Turkey faces an election that could decide its future as a democracy
For subscribers only: to see how we design each week’s cover, sign up to our weekly Cover Story newsletter.
